Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Amplifying Community Readiness to Increase Public Access to Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This exploratory project in open science will examine and address uptake of the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR) for deposition of metadata records for research datasets that support validation of results in publications, or for data resources described in publications. In particular, there is interest in how practices are changing for the use of data identifiers (e.g. DOIs). The project will partner with domain and technical organizations to extend the reach of this work. Studying researcher’s current data production, planning for deposit or exposing those data, and roles of their Data Management Plan (DMP), will provide insights on how to foster change – away from the view of “DMP as a box-checking” – toward the use of the DMP as a value-add process for linking research project planning with increased transparency for the benefit of public access.

This study will begin with two different research areas: Initial work will focus on the Geosciences, and computationally-based communities (e.g. Data Science and AI/Machine Learning). For the Geosciences, there are opportunities to improve data publishing practices, by obtaining DOIs and increasing data citation. At the intersections of the Geosciences, semantic technologies, computing and informatics, there are Open Knowledge Networks which have the potential to generate new data resources to support solutions to societal grand challenges. Across the Data Science and AI-related communities, there is a need for better access to high quality datasets, models, and infrastructure; currently, resources for locating, accessing, and selecting such datasets are scattered and variable. Utilizing the uptake of the NSF PAR system for research data may facilitate increased access to datasets for research and education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research data and code are fundamental to scientific review processes, claim verification, and the production of new knowledge. Increasingly, these products are viewed as first class research objects that are integral to community expectations about publishing and Open Science. There are many pathways for making data available, most depend on essential components of infrastructure, including a managed facility or repository, persistent identifier services, and an information system that supports indexing and cataloging of descriptive records that point to the data and related products (e.g. scientific software or code). 

One approach to improving access to the results of federally-funded research includes the expansion of reporting requirements for grant recipients, which will require investigators to: acquire persistent identifiers for data (e.g. Digital Object Identifiers); generate high-quality descriptive metadata; select a repository for the data and related material; and, submit records about these deposits to funding agency reporting systems such as the National Science Foundation (NSF) Public Access Repository (PAR). Uptake of these services and meeting requirements to increase public access to these research products requires deeper understanding of how researchers and research communities are prepared to undertake this new reporting.

This award funded several activities to address community understanding of the Public Access landscape and readiness to meet evolving Public Access requirements. To address community readiness, materials were developed on evolving federal initiatives for Public Access, and webinars delivered to several communities in the earth and environmental sciences, as well as academic library groups. These community engagement activities addressed advances in Public Access, developments at the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR), and the NSF Data Pilot. Most of these presentations were focused on new federal reports, emergent policies and NSF PAR; others included the current efforts to address the FAIR Principles, which are aim to make data Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable. Scientific and data community organizations have tremendous reach across the wide network of researchers, and are able to serve as a conduit for the awareness and understanding needed to improve practices around the management and representation of data and related materials that explain the results of federally-funded research. 

An additional activity for the project was the production of a “Public Access Colloquium,” that was held as a virtual convening in fall, 2021. In collaboration with the Association of Research Libraries, this meeting was designed to highlight NSF Public Access awards and facilitate cross-community discussion on societal impacts and benefits to increased access to data. One aim was to bring together a group of experts who do not typically interact, but who have rich perspectives with which to inform one another. In addition to talks from funded Public Access projects, the agenda included a talk on “Open Knowledge Networks to Address Societal Challenges;” a introduction to the work of the Office of Science and Technology Policy's Scientific Integrity Task Force, which was developing reports and guidance on that topic; and, a presentation the National Institutes of Health's AIM AHEAD program and innovations for data sharing. An important result was cross-pollination of ideas and approaches for addressing knowledge discovery and production across scientific and scholarly domains.

Research on the evolving data practices of individual researchers was a significant element of this project. Scientific work is conducted across increasingly complex data environments. Interviewing individual researchers on their current data production and management practices, as well as plans for deposit or sharing those data, provides insight on how to foster changes needed to increase or improve public access. Interviews and related data collection focused on the soil sciences, a broad field addressing grand challenges related to, for example, understanding the impacts of land use on the environment, as well as managing soil nutrients to increase food production. Soil science is seen as particularly relevant area for study, as the data are complex and computational methods are integral to understanding these grand challenge questions. Across the span of the project, more than 20 interviews were conducted with soil scientists and data experts; findings are forthcoming.
